text: [Applause]
how did we did this mine you're not an
American you're an African who ends up
in America we didn't land on Plymouth
Rock Plymouth Rock landed on us in his
lifetime Malcolm X was an incendiary and
controversial figure it's somewhat
surprising therefore to find that in his
memoir Dreams from My Father
President Barack Obama cites Malcolm X
as an early role model but the reason is
that Malcolm X's story is one of self
transformation a story that he tells in
his autobiography and that Spike Lee
tells in his wonderful film biography
Malcolm X before there was any such
thing as a Republican or a Democrat we
were black the idea of a movie about
Malcolm X had been kicking around
Hollywood for a long time in the late
1960s James Baldwin worked on a
screenplay for a long time
the director Norman Jewison was attached
and finally after some struggle and
controversy Spike Lee took over the
project and what a movie he made it has
song and dance numbers wild period
costumes violence sex an amazingly
beautiful sequence involving Malcolm's
pilgrimage to Mecca
and a handful of terrific supporting
performances including Spike Lee himself
Angela Bassett and the great Delroy
Lindo as the gangster West Indian Archie
smudge risk-on was yours
what anchors this movie and makes it not
just entertaining but genuinely great is
Denzel Washington's performance as
Malcolm X he provides a portrait of a
man in the process of self
transformation he starts out in
obscurity as a nobody a loser he rises
to become a fairly successful criminal
then he goes to prison where he
discovers the teachings of the Nation of
Islam when he gets out of jail he
becomes a foot soldier a loyal
lieutenant of Elijah Muhammad
and then he breaks away from Elijah
Muhammad and begins to explore and
articulate a vision that's not just
based on racial justice but on an idea
of universal dignity many men today my
friends are black red yellow brown and
white this last phase of Malcolm's self
creation was tragically cut short but it
is the source of his legacy the ideas
that he came to at the very end of his
life were the ones that so inspired the
young Barack Obama and the whole thing
coalesce is in one of the most powerful
and interesting and rich and I think
newly relevant portraits that we have
about how a man invents and changes
himself
[Music]
